videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Coordinating Care for a Person with a Rare Genetic Disorder
videoDescription: When a genetic disorder is identified in a person, there may be a sense of relief at the end of a diagnostic odyssey. However, there is often no playbook or manual to guide the person, their family, and providers. Fortunately, Patient Advocacy Groups (PAGs) or Disease Advocacy Organizations (DAOs) provide a community to fill many gaps. This presentation from February 12, 2025, with Angela E. Lin, MD, FACMG, will hopefully be received as a pep talk to encourage people to coordinate care even when a person is unique.
caption: false

videoTitle: Our Milestone Second Successful Xenotransplant
videoDescription: Our Mass General experts reached another medical milestone on Saturday, January 25. This day marked the completion of our second successful xenotransplant of a genetically-edited pig kidney into a living recipient. 66-year-old Tim Andrews of Concord, N.H., is now the fourth person in the world to receive a genetically-edited pig kidney. In March 2024, Mass General made history with the world‚Äôs first transplant of a genetically-edited pig kidney into a living human. We continue to push the boundaries of transplantation and work toward solutions for the global organ shortage. Read more about this groundbreaking medical achievement: https://www.massgeneral.org/news/press-release/mgh-performs-second-xenotransplant-of-genetically-edited-pig-kidney-into-living-recipient
tags: pig kidney,transplant,CRISPR,gene editing,genetic,Tim Andrews,Timothy Andrews,renal failure,Riella,Kawai,Elias,MGH,Massachusetts General Hospital,Mass General,kidney disease,dialysis,MGB,Boston,organ transplant
caption: true

They guide participants in setting realistic, actionable goals to build healthy habits for the new year. This program is part of the Cancer Center Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Cancer Center at Mass General.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Glaucoma and Eye Health for Older Adults
videoDescription: January is National Glaucoma Awareness Month. Glaucoma is a leading cause of vision loss and blindness in the United States and worldwide, yet half of people who have glaucoma don't know they have it. Older adults are especially at risk, but regular screening and consistent treatment can help prevent vision loss from glaucoma. In this presentation from January 21, 2025, Dr. Silas Wang discusses what glaucoma is, who is at higher risk, how to be screened, and how it is treated. He also reviews some tips for maintaining eye health as you get older. This program is a collaboration between Mass General Blum Center and Mass Eye and Ear.

videoTitle: Congratulations Nobel Laureate Gary Ruvkun, PhD!
videoDescription: Colleagues, friends and family members share their heartfelt congratulations with Gary Ruvkun, PhD, recipient of the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his role in the discovery of microRNA and its role in post-transcriptional gene regulation. He shares the award with his collaborator Victor Ambros, PhD, of the University of Massachusetts Medical School.
caption: false

videoTitle: Healthcare Sustainability - Transforming Clinical Practice in the Face of Climate Change
videoDescription: The U.S. healthcare sector is responsible for a substantial amount of environmental pollution with negative impacts on planetary and human health. This presentation provides information on the sources of this pollution using a recent carbon footprint of the MGB system, and demonstrates how clinical activities can drive pollution and represent opportunities for improvement. Two examples relevant to internal medicine are highlighted including single use vs. reusable products and low carbon asthma care.
caption: false

videoDescription: James Berry, MD, MPH of Massachusetts General Hospital and Robert Bowser, PhD of Barrow Neurological Institute presented updates about the Access for All in ALS (ALL ALS) Consortium and discussed the importance of biomarker studies in the field of ALS research. videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Grief Around the Holidays
videoDescription: The holiday season is often a time of joy and togetherness. However, for those who are grieving, it can also bring profound sadness and loneliness. This November 19, 2024 session, led by Maryclare O‚ÄôBrien-Wilson, M.Div, BCC, and Mary Barber Bussiere, MSW, LICSW, PMH-C, aims to provide a supportive virtual space for individuals to gain an understanding of grief, explore their feelings, and learn practical coping strategies to navigate this challenging time. This program is part of the Spiritual Care Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Spiritual Care Department at Mass General.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Awaken Your Senses - Mindfulness Practices for Daily Life
videoDescription: November 20, 2024, led by Carmen Alvarez, MHA: Discover how engaging all of your senses can bring a deeper level of presence and appreciation to everyday experiences. Through a mindful sensory exploration, participants gain insights into the richness of life often overlooked when we are not fully present. This program is part of the Blum Center Well-Being Series.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Caring for the Whole Person: The Role of Palliative Care and Hospice
videoDescription: In this presentation from November 18, 2024, Elizabeth Lindenberger, MD, discusses the role of palliative care and hospice in supporting patients with serious illness and their families. Specifically, she reviews the many ways that palliative care can support patients of any age and at any stage of illness. Dr. Lindenberger also discusses the role of hospice care in supporting patients and their families at the end of life and the types of services are included with this care.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: What Patients Should Know About Living with Immunotherapy
videoDescription: In this presentation from November 13, 2024, the Immunotherapy Team at the Mass General Cancer Center provides an overview of immunotherapy for cancer treatment. They discuss how immunotherapy has significantly changed cancer treatment as well as the different types of side effects that can occur with immunotherapy and how to manage them. They answer common questions, including when immunotherapy can be restarted after side effects and fertility considerations with immunotherapy. They also discuss survivorship, including steroid side effects, survivorship care plans, and communication with your primary care doctor. This program is part of the Cancer Center Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Cancer Center at Mass General.
caption: false

videoTitle: Highlights from the Fourth Annual Conference on Precision Psychiatry 2024
videoDescription: The CPP's Fourth Annual Conference on Precision Psychiatry, "Innovation to Implementation", was held virtually on September 26th and 27th, 2024. The conference featured many expert speakers, including Keynotes by Dr. Isaac Kohane, Professor & Chair within the Dept. of Biomedical Informatics at Harvard Medical School, and Dr. Rosalind Picard, Founder and Director of Affective Computing Research at MIT. Find out more about previous and upcoming CPP events at https://www.massgeneral.org/psychiatry/research/precision-psychiatry/annual-conference
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Lifestyle Medicine for Patients and Caregivers
videoDescription: Lifestyle medicine is the use of healthy lifestyle behaviors to improve both physical and mental health. Lifestyle medicine can aid recovery in people with cancer and help to reduce the risk of other chronic diseases. Healthy lifestyle behaviors are also important self-care for caregivers supporting their loved ones with cancer. In this presentation from November 1, 2024, three oncology (cancer) care providers from the MGH Cancer Center Lifestyle Medicine Program describe what lifestyle medicine is and give practical tips for its use. We are also joined by a patient who shares her lifestyle medicine journey as a program participant and a caregiver. This program is part of the Cancer Center Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Cancer Center at Mass General.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: High Cholesterol
videoDescription: In this presentation from November 7, 2024, Linda Hemphill, MD, FACC, FAHA, FNLA, reviews the role of cholesterol in heart attack and stroke. She defines ‚Äúhigh cholesterol‚Äù as well as discusses ways to manage cholesterol to prevent heart attacks and strokes.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Proton Therapy - A Novel Radiation Therapy Pioneered by Mass General
videoDescription: Proton therapy is a special form of radiation therapy that offers clinical benefits for some patients. Massachusetts General Hospital is a pioneer of proton therapy and offers the only treatment facility in New England. In this presentation from November 6, 2024, Helen A. Shih, MD, MS, MPH, FASTRO, discusses the history, why it is special, and how it is used today. This program is part of the Cancer Center Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Cancer Center at Mass General.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: I Was Diagnosed with Pancreatic Cancer, What‚Äôs Next?
videoDescription: Pancreatic cancer is the fourth leading cause of cancer in the United States. Patients and their families are often full of questions and fears about what the future holds. In this presentation from November 4, 2024, Laurie Miller, DNP, APRN-BC, CNRN, discusses prevention, diagnosis, medical treatment, and some of the emotional concerns tied to this disease. This program is part of the Cancer Center Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Cancer Center at Mass General.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Signs, Symptoms, and Management of Diverticulitis
videoDescription: Diverticulitis is a gastrointestinal condition when an irregular outpouching of your colon (large intestine) becomes inflamed or infected. It can cause abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and constipation. In this presentation from October 30, 2024, Kevin Knoblock, MHA, MBA, MSN, NP, reviews what diverticulitis is, what might cause it, and how we treat it.
caption: false

videoTitle: The Living Kidney Donation Surgery
videoDescription: Understand the full surgical process for living kidney donation, from giving informed consent to undergoing the procedure, known as a donor nephrectomy, and beyond. This video provides a clear overview of the timeline, highlights potential complications, and offers a reassuring look at what you can expect during the surgery and recovery phase. To learn more about living donation, visit https://www.massgeneral.org/transplant/about/living-donor-program For questions about your unique situation, please contact your living kidney donation team.

videoTitle: Psychosocial Factors in Living Kidney Donation: What to Expect
videoDescription: This video explores the emotional, financial, and psychosocial challenges that living kidney donors may encounter. These topics are addressed on an individual basis with your Living Donor Social Worker. videoTitle: Additional Risks and Considerations for Living Kidney Donor
videoDescription: Beyond immediate medical factors, living kidney donors should be aware of additional risks when deciding to donate. This video covers potential long-term implications, including considerations around pregnancy after donation and what might happen if a donor later develops end-stage kidney disease, requiring a transplant. We emphasize the importance of making an informed decision and understanding all potential outcomes. To learn more about living donation, visit https://www.massgeneral.org/transplant/about/living-donor-program For questions about your unique situation, please contact your living kidney donation team.

videoDescription: In this presentation from October 9, 2024, MGH HAVEN Advocates, Angelina Rogers, MSW, LICSW, and Abby Farrand, LICSW, discuss the critical role of healthcare professionals in addressing intimate partner violence (IPV) through advocacy and intervention. videoDescription: In this presentation from September 23, 2024, in recognition of National Recovery Month, MGH Recovery Coaches with lived experiences, Brittany Deruosi, Hansel Lugo, and Nick DeSimone, share short valuable discussions. They share their perspectives on bias and stigma, the importance of connections in recovery, and hope with finding purposes.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Exercise and Aging - Maintaining Motivation to Move
videoDescription: Exercise and physical activity can help you stay healthy as you age. In this presentation from September 17, 2024, Lisa LaRowe, PhD, discusses the profound benefits of exercise, including improved mobility, mood, and overall quality of life. She also provides practical recommendations for incorporating exercise into your daily routine and discusses evidence-based strategies to stay motivated and committed to your fitness goals.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis and Treatment
videoDescription: There have been many recent exciting developments in Alzheimer's disease diagnosis and treatment, but it can be hard to make sense of all of the changing information. In this presentation from September 11, 2024, John Dickson, MD, PhD, provides an overview of Alzheimer's disease and discusses the current state of diagnosis and treatment, including anti-amyloid therapy.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Carrier Screening Recommendations for Pregnant and Family Planning Individuals
videoDescription: In this presentation from September 5, 2024, Kelsey Reynolds, MS, CGC, discusses current carrier screening recommendations and test options for families who are pregnant or family planning. She reviews how family history may impact carrier screening recommendations. Kelsey also shares questions patients should ask themselves to help them select the best test for their family. The Genetics Series is a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Center for Genomic Medicine at Mass General.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Drowning Prevention and Summer Safety
videoDescription: Summer offers lots of wonderful opportunities for families to enjoy the nice weather. It is important to remember to keep yourself and your family safe around any body of water, including pools, lakes, and the ocean. In the United States, drowning is the #1 cause of death for children ages 1-4 years old. In Massachusetts, there are several drowning deaths each year in all age groups. Drowning can be prevented and there are steps you can take to maximize your safety. In this presentation from July 24, 2024, in recognition of Drowning Prevention Day, Toby Raybould, MS, shares drowning prevention and summer safety strategies.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Climate Change Challenges in 2024 and Beyond
videoDescription: Climate change challenges are increasing each year with the warming of the planet. Heat exposure is a challenge and other health consequences including exposure to poor air quality are increasing annually. In this presentation from June 25, 2024, Suellen Breakey, PhD, RN, offers a lens on health consequences of climate change in 2024 and beyond. This program is part of the Climate Change and Health Series, a collaboration among the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center, the MGH Center for the Environment and Health, and the MGH Institute of Health Professions Center for Climate Change, Climate Justice, and Health.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Sickle Cell Disease - A Portrait of Racism in the American Healthcare System
videoDescription: Sickle cell disease is a life-threatening blood disorder that primarily impacts Black and Brown patients across the globe. In recognition of World Sickle Cell Day, this presentation will discuss the disease, its limited treatments, and the intrinsic racism within our healthcare system that has limited clinical advances and stifled the care of our patients for decades. This program is part of the Disability Education Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Council on Disability Awareness at Mass General.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: I Have a Family Member with Dementia. Am I at Risk?
videoDescription: Did you know that while dementia is a common symptom with many causes, genetic causes are rare? In this presentation from June 10, 2024, Diane Lucente, MS, CGC, discusses the role of genetic testing and how genetic testing has evolved over time. This program is part of the Genetics Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Center for Genomic Medicine at Mass General.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: What is Fibromyalgia?
videoDescription: In recognition of Fibromyalgia Awareness Month, this presentation from May 14, 2024, Jonathan Hausmann, MD, aims to demystify fibromyalgia, providing an overview of its symptoms and the challenges in diagnosis. He discusses how pain is perceived and processed in the brain in fibromyalgia and other chronic primary pain syndromes. He also reviews the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to treatment, including lifestyle modifications, medications, sleep hygiene, and novel therapies shown to decrease pain.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Scleroderma - Symptoms, Diagnosis, and Treatments
videoDescription: Scleroderma is a complex autoimmune disease that can affect a number of different organs including the skin, lungs, kidneys, and gastrointestinal tract. In this presentation from June 5, 2024, in recognition of Scleroderma Awareness Month, Laura Yockey, MD, PhD, reviews how we diagnose scleroderma, how different organs can be affected, and some of the treatment options.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: The Connection Between Our Breath and Our Emotions
videoDescription: Our breath serves as a bridge between our conscious and unconscious mind, influencing our emotional states through its rhythm and depth. Techniques like deep breathing and mindfulness can help regulate emotions by harnessing the power of our breath to calm the nervous system and reduce stress. In this presentation from May 15, 2024, in recognition of Mental Health Awareness Month, Carmen Alvarez reviews the intimate connection between our breath and emotions, and how they can cultivate greater self-awareness and emotional resilience in navigating life's challenges. This program is part of the Blum Center Well-Being Series.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Climate Change Impacts on Youth Mental Health
videoDescription: Climate change is a major public health concern. Mental health is an area significantly affected by climate change through direct and existential impacts. Youth represent a particularly vulnerable population due to longer exposure to impacts over a greater proportion of their development. In this presentation from April 22, 2024, in recognition of Earth Day, James McKowen, PhD, reviews the impacts of climate change on youth mental health and discusses strategies for supporting wellness and resilience.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Alcohol Use Disorders in the United States
videoDescription: Alcohol-related harms in the United States have increased over the past decade, dramatically during the pandemic. Unhealthy alcohol use, including excessive alcohol use and alcohol use disorders, has significantly increased in all gender, racial/ethnic, and age groups. Alcohol-related healthcare utilization and deaths, including alcohol-associated liver disease, have exploded over the past decade, specifically driven by alcohol use disorders. In this presentation from April 11, 2024, Gene Lambert, MD, MBA, FACP, FASAM, discusses the shifting landscape of alcohol use disorders, its societal impact, and treatment strategies.
caption: false

videoTitle: Strategies to help those w/ Autism Spectrum Disorder & Other Developmental Disabilities Access Care
videoDescription: In this presentation from April 8, 2024, Jill Pineda, PhD, discusses barriers to medical care for individuals with autism spectrum disorder and other developmental disabilities. Practical strategies for decreasing anxiety and improving care for these individuals are provided. The use of systematic desensitization, an evidence-based strategy for decreasing anxiety around medical procedures, is reviewed and highlighted through case examples.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Obesity and the New World of Weight Loss Treatment
videoDescription: Obesity rates are growing in the United States, affecting both adults and kids. Obesity is linked to an increased risk of several other medical conditions, including heart disease, diabetes, and depression. In this presentation from April 3, 2024, Sreevidya Bodepudi, DO, and Karan Chhabra, MD, MSc, review the causes and complications of obesity as well as medication and surgical treatment options.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: The Connection Between Stress and Our Nervous System
videoDescription: In this presentation from April 5, 2024, in recognition of National Stress Awareness Month, Carmen Alvarez reviews the physiological relationship between stress and the nervous system, including the role of the sympathetic and parasympathetic response. She discusses common stressors and their impact on the nervous system's functioning, the body's "fight or flight" response, and its implications for overall well-being. Practical techniques and tools to help regulate your nervous system's response to stress as well as promote relaxation, resilience, and improved coping mechanisms are also shared. This program is part of the Blum Center Well-Being Series.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Pharmacogenomics
videoDescription: Testing genes to see how your body responds to and interacts with drugs is a way of personalizing medication ‚Äì selecting a medication at a dose that is safe and effective. However, currently there are limitations to how the results can be used. In this presentation from March 12, 2024, Elizabeth Fieg, MS, CGC, reviews what pharmacogenomics (PGx) testing can and can‚Äôt tell us about personalized medicine. This program is part of the Genetics Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Center for Genomic Medicine at Mass General.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Climate Change and Considerations for Populations with Disabilities
videoDescription: Climate change is responsible for many adverse health consequences. For those with limitations in physical, cognitive, or psychological abilities, our changing climate requires a unique lens to provide optimal care for these populations. In this presentation from March 26, 2024, Patrice Nicholas, DNSc, DHL (Hon), MPH, MS, RN, NP-C, FAAN, and Sarah McKinnon, OT, OTR, OTD, BCPR, MPA, FAOTA, FNAP, discuss considerations for these populations, and ways to promote awareness and advocate for accessibility and inclusion. This program is part of the Climate Change and Health Series, a collaboration among the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center, the MGH Center for the Environment and Health, and the MGH Institute of Health Professions Center for Climate Change, Climate Justice, and Health.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Menopause and Heart Health
videoDescription: More women in the United States are living longer, and some will spend nearly half their lives post-menopausal. In this presentation from March 11, 2024, Colleen M. Harrington, MD, FACC, FASE, discusses the connection between menopause and heart health. She also shares how to prevent heart disease before, during, and after menopause.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Cerebral Palsy - Diagnosis and Management
videoDescription: Cerebral palsy is one of the most common causes of disability in childhood with a range of causes. In this presentation from March 27, 2024, David Dredge, MD, and Brian Wishart, DO, MMS, FAAP, discuss the clinical features of cerebral palsy and review common etiologies. Additionally, they review approaches to treatment of muscle tone and associated symptoms. This program is part of the Disability Education Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Council on Disability Awareness at Mass General.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Skin Pigment Concerns in Children
videoDescription: Our skin gets its color from a pigment called melanin. When melanin-producing cells in our body become damaged or unhealthy, it affects melanin production and our skin color. In this presentation from March 18, 2024, Anna Cristina (Cristy) Garza-Mayers, MD, PhD, FAAD, discusses common skin pigment conditions in children. She also reviews the available therapeutic approaches to these conditions, including their safety and how well they work. Lastly, Dr. Garza-Mayers reviews the role of multidisciplinary care in caring for children‚Äôs skin. This program is part of the Dermatology Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Department of Dermatology at Mass General.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Telemedicine in the Post-Pandemic Era
videoDescription: In this presentation from March 25, 2024, Shinjita Das, MD, MPH, discusses the major changes during the pandemic that have allowed us to widely use telemedicine. She also discusses the current state of telehealth and what the future may hold. The conversation centers on ways to include telemedicine as part of an ‚Äúomnichannel‚Äù healthcare experience across the care continuum. This program is part of the Dermatology Series, a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and the Department of Dermatology at Mass General.

videoTitle: Massachusetts General Hospital Announces World‚Äôs First Genetically-Edited Pig Kidney Transplant
videoDescription: At a press conference on Thursday, March 22, 2024, Massachusetts General Hospital announced a team from its Transplant Center completed the world‚Äôs first successful genetically-edited pig kidney transplant into a live human. The pig kidney, which was specifically bred and genetically-edited for human compatibility, was transplanted into Mr. Rick Slayman of Weymouth, Massachusetts, on Saturday, March 16, 2024 during a four-hour procedure. For more information, see the full press release here: https://www.massgeneral.org/news/press-release/worlds-first-genetically-edited-pig-kidney-transplant-into-living-recipient For more information see our Frequently Asked Questions here: https://www.massgeneral.org/news/kidney-xenotransplant-faqs

videoTitle: Climate, Health, & Equity: The Case for Collective Action from the Health System
videoDescription: Climate change is not just an environmental concern but an imminent threat to individual and population health and a major challenge to health equity. Moreover, the health sector significantly contributes to greenhouse gas emissions. Recognizing their roles as healthcare providers and contributors to the climate crisis, clinicians and health professionals have a moral obligation to emphasize the profound significance of climate impacts on human health and equity at the national level. This lecture provides an overview of efforts ‚Äì from the US National Academy of Medicine and others ‚Äì which address the intersection of climate change and health, with an aim to raise awareness about the immediate threats to patient health and build a proactive path forward for the health sector.
caption: false

videoTitle: Burning plastic waste and climate change: Can implementation science fix this global problem?
videoDescription: Open burning of plastic waste is practiced widely across the globe and exposures to air pollution from plastic waste is harmful to human health. In this presentation, the effects of plastic waste burning/incineration on global climate change will be discussed. A case study will highlight the ECOLECTIVOS project, an implementation research study that is evaluating the uptake and sustainability of intervention strategies to reduce use, recycle, and repurpose plastic that will lead to reductions in household-level plastic burning in rural, indigenous Guatemalan communities.
caption: false

videoTitle: Peggy's journey at Mass General's Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance
videoDescription: Meet Peggy, a brave kidney recipient who underwent the innovative Tolerance Induction protocol through the Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance #CCTT at the Mass General Transplant Center. Tolerance induction is the process of reeducating an organ recipient's immune system so that it recognizes the transplanted organ as "self". The goal is to reduce or eliminate the need for life-long anti-rejection medications. Peggy's younger brother and hero, Stephen, donated his kidney and bone marrow allowing her to live a drug-free life after her kidney transplant. Learn more about this groundbreaking protocol by visiting https://www.massgeneral.org/tolerance #organrejectionprevention #kidneytransplant #antirejection #drugfreetransplant #chronickidneydisease #YouTube
caption: false

videoTitle: Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance at Mass General Hospital
videoDescription: Physician-scientists at the Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance #CCTT at Mass General Hospital have an innovative approach to organ transplantation - tolerance induction. This groundbreaking approach allows for the reduced or eliminated need anti-rejection medications after transplant. Explore a new era in organ transplants without immunosuppressants. Visit https://www.massgeneral.org/tolerance #organrejectionprevention #kidneytransplant #antirejection #drugfreetransplant #chronickidneydisease #YouTube

videoTitle: What is the MGH Transplant Tolerance Protocol?
videoDescription: Physician-scientists at the Mass General Hospital Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance #CCTT have developed a unique procedure, The Tolerance Protocol, which allows organ recipients to accept a transplanted organ without the need for anti-rejection medications. videoTitle: Is the MGH Transplant Tolerance Protocol Available to All Organ Recipients?
videoDescription: Currently, the Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance #CCTT at Mass General Hospital is limited to kidney transplant recipients from living donors. We hope to expand The Tolerance Protocol ‚Äì which aims to reduce or eliminate the need for life-long immunosuppressive medications ‚Äì to deceased donor recipients and other organ transplants, including livers and hearts. videoTitle: Is the MGH Transplant Tolerance Protocol Safe?
videoDescription: The Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance #CCTT at Mass General Hospital prioritizes quality and safety. With over 30 years of pre-clinical and clinical research conducted at MGH, experts are confident in The Tolerance Protocol. This protocol aims to reduce or eliminate the need for life-long immunosuppressive medications by re-educating organ recipient‚Äôs immune system. videoTitle: Medication-free After Transplant: Peggy‚Äôs tolerance success story
videoDescription: Peggy B., a kidney transplant recipient, talks about her unique transplant journey and how an innovative protocol through the MGH Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance #CCTT has given her new life. The Tolerance Protocol, which Peggy calls ‚Äúa cure,‚Äù aims to reduce or eliminate the need for life-long immunosuppressive medications by re-educating organ recipient‚Äôs immune system. Immunosuppressants, or anti-rejection drugs, are required after transplant to help prevent organ rejection, a major complication that can result in damage to a transplanted organ or even its loss. Learn more about The Tolerance Protocol at the Legorreta CCTT by visiting: https://www.massgeneral.org/tolerance For more information about the Mass General Transplant Center, visit: https://www.massgeneral.org/transplant #Innovation #ToleranceInduction #OneKidneyForLife #KidneyTransplant #Immunosuppression #MGH

videoTitle: Alison Graziano, RDN, LDN, Discusses Nutrition Counseling at Mass General Concierge Medicine
videoDescription: Originally from Buffalo, NY, Alison Graziano, RD, LDN, is no stranger to the cold Boston winters. As the in-house Registered Dietitian Nutritionist, Alison holds a Bachelor of Nutritional Science from Cornell University. She completed her dietetic internship at Brigham and Women‚Äôs Hospital before joining Mass General‚Äôs Concierge and Executive Health practices in 2021. Many people believe dietitians are the food police ‚Äì this simply isn‚Äôt true. Alison understands that fad diets and blanket nutrition recommendations don‚Äôt work. Instead, she takes a compassionate approach to nutrition counseling that tailors balanced nutrition solutions to meet each patient‚Äôs unique lifestyle and health needs. Alison‚Äôs clinical interests are in prevention of chronic disease through nutrition and lifestyle intervention while improving our relationship with food and our body. In her free time, she is an avid alpine skier and home cook.
caption: false

videoTitle: Lisa Keer, National Board Certified Health Coach, Talks Health Coaching at MGH Concierge Medicine
videoDescription: Lisa Keer, MS, NASM-CPT, NBC-HWC, joined Mass General Concierge Medicine practice after 16 years in independent practice as an integrative Health Coach and personal trainer/Pilates instructor. She is a Duke Integrative Medicine Trained Integrative Health Coach (2015) and completed the Health and Wellness Coach Certifying Exam to become a National Board-certified Health and Wellness Coach in 2017, as part of the first cohort to sit for the exam. Lisa coaches adults of all ages and life stages. She has helped people to make lasting lifestyle changes around fitness, sleep, and stress reduction. She has also coached extensively on topics like self-care for caregivers (children at home/aging parents), professional and personal growth/development for mid to late career professionals, and proactive approaches to aging while extending one‚Äôs healthspan. She is a competitive equestrian (dressage), a former competitive amateur boxer and an avid cross-country skier.

videoTitle: The Tolerance Protocol: Inducing Tolerance by Teaching the Immune System (2)
videoDescription: The Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance #CCTT at Mass General Hospital has created an animation to provide a high-level glimpse into our unique protocol for achieving tolerance after kidney transplantation. This protocol aims to reduce or eliminate the need for life-long immunosuppressive medications by re-educating the host's immune system. With the elimination of immunosuppressants, the Tolerance Protocol offers kidney transplant patients a better quality of life. This experimental protocol is available through the Legorreta CCTT at Mass General Hospital, with the plan to expand this opportunity to other organs in the future. The Legorreta CCTT aims to make tolerance induction the standard of care for post-transplant patients, becoming the world‚Äôs leading Center dedicated to preventing organ rejection without the use of lifelong immunosuppression. Learn more about The Tolerance Protocol at the Legorreta CCTT by visiting: https://www.massgeneral.org/transplant/transplant-programs/tolerance For more information about the Mass General Transplant Center, visit: https://www.massgeneral.org/transplant #Innovation #ToleranceInduction #OneKidneyForLife #KidneyTransplant #Immunosuppression

videoTitle: Welcome to Mass General International Concierge Medicine

videoDescription: The Legorreta Center for Clinical Transplant Tolerance #CCTT at Mass General Hospital has created an animation to provide a high-level glimpse into the injurious immune response called a "rejection episode." This major post-transplant complication is mitigated by the use of immunosuppressant medications. In this presentation from October 23, 2023, Danielle L. Karthik, MS, CCC-SLP, Courtney Perrigo, MS, CCC-SLP, and Jacqueline Toscano, SLPD, CCC-SLP, discuss the meaning of stuttering, debunk common myths, and challenge societal expectations for children and adolescents who stutter. videoTitle: Supporting Regenerative Agriculture with Yellow Pea Falafel
videoDescription: In the fall of 2022, Brigham and Women‚Äôs Hospital partnered with Health Care Without Harm, CommonWealth Kitchen, and Aurora Mills Farm to add a new product to their retail menu -- yellow pea falafel. This falafel has since been featured in their retail cafeteria and is soon to be on the patient menu, increasing the number of plant-based food options and reducing food-related greenhouse gas emissions. The development of this falafel has helped to create a market for farmers to grow yellow peas, a regenerative crop that is grown in between other crop cycles to replenish the soil with nutrients. Join us to learn the story behind the yellow pea falafel and its beneficial impact on local communities and the environment.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Tips to Promote Safe Video Game and Digital Media Use Habits
videoDescription: Video games and digital media have become one of the most favorite play activities for our children, and digital media has infused far into their (and our) daily lives. Parents and providers express a lot of concern about the effects of violent or suggestive content of video games and digital media on their children. However, existing research has not been able to conclusively establish any such link. Instead, findings reveal the several circumstances of digital media access to be associated with overall wellbeing of children. In this presentation from June 29, 2023, Dr. Atilla Ceranoglu shares tips on how to help your child build good digital media habits while playing their favorite video games, social media outlets, or the internet. The MGfC Family-Centered Care Series is a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and Mass General for Children.

videoTitle: A New and Optimal Treatment for Frostbite
videoDescription: David Shahian, MD, director for Quality at the Vascular Center, and Gregory Walker, MD, Interventional Radiology Residency program director, speak about Dr. Walkers recently published review article on a treatment for frostbite. Dr. Walker and his colleagues published the article in the New England Journal of Medicine. After a patient sustained frostbite to multiple areas of his body, doctors at Massachusetts General Hospital successfully treated the patient, resulting in no amputations and an extensive rehabilitation process. These successful results piqued the interest of these doctors to investigate an optimal treatment plan for frostbite. Dr. Walker speaks on partnering with the Burns Service and putting a new algorithm in place at Mass General to treat frostbite successfully. Dr. Walker continues to say how the process has blossomed from a single isolated case to now being the mainstream treatment with remarkable results.

videoTitle: The American Chemical Society Installation of the National Landmark: Dr. Saul Hertz - Oct. 8, 2021
videoDescription: Somewhere in the basement of the Bulfinch Building, Dr. Hertz carried out experiments with results that would forever change medicine. What began as an investigation into thyroid disorders widened into an entirely new field: nuclear medicine,‚Äù said David F.M. Brown, MD, Mass General President, during an Oct. 8, 2021 landmark dedication ceremony at Mass General. ‚ÄúToday, more than 10 million patients in the United States are treated each year with radioisotopes of various kinds. We are proud that the Mass General was the site of such a significant medical milestone, and we thank the American Chemical Society (ACS) for this extraordinary tribute to a pioneer in medicine.‚Äù Additional speakers paid tribute to Hertz were his daughter Barbara Hertz; Katherine Lee, PhD, of the ACS Board of Directors; Sumner Fanger, a close friend of Hertz; and Anna Sromek, PhD, past chair of the Northeastern section of the ACS. The ACS established the National Historic Chemical Landmarks Program in 1992 to enhance public appreciation for the contributions of the chemical sciences to modern life in the nation and to encourage a sense of pride in their practitioners.

videoTitle: Climate Change & Health Symposium 2023: Achieving Planetary Health through Sustainable Action
videoDescription: Climate change is a growing public health concern with implications for safety and well-being; nutrition and food security; food, water, and vector-borne diseases; and mental health. Climate change and the social determinants of health are closely aligned, contributing to disparate environmental exposures and health inequalities, as a disproportionate number of low-income individuals, some communities of color, and those with higher vulnerability to disease and chronic health conditions are at risk. This symposium brings together national experts and faculty from the MGH Institute of Health Professions School of Nursing Center for Climate Change, Climate Justice, and Health, Massachusetts General Hospital Center for the Environment and Health, and Brigham and Women's Hospital to discuss sustainable strategies to achieve human and planetary health.

videoTitle: Bridging the Disparities Gap: Understanding and Implementing the OPTN/UNOS Policy
videoDescription: The goal of this special webinar is to educate participants about a recent policy change by the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) and the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) and how it may affect kidney transplant candidates nationwide, especially those who identify as Black or African American. Our experts explained the new waiting time adjustment policy and Mass General Transplant Center's plan to address it. They also answered audience questions and provided additional resources. Don't miss this opportunity to stay informed about and empowered throughout your transplant journey! Learn more about the OPTN/UNOS policy by visiting this site: https://optn.transplant.hrsa.gov/patients/by-organ/kidney/understanding-the-proposal-to-require-race-neutral-egfr-calculations/ Learn about how Massachusetts General Hospital is addressing this policy for its patients: https://www.massgeneral.org/transplant/about/news/unos-policy-update-egfr

videoTitle: An Incidental Finding, Life-Saving Care: Surgery to Remove Lindsey‚Äôs Pancreatic Tumor
videoDescription: Lindsey Scheyer was rushed to the Newton Wellesley Hospital emergency room after returning home from summer camp one day feeling nauseous and bothered by a jabbing pain in her abdomen. It was there that she was evaluated by Peter Masiakos, MD, a pediatric provider at Newton-Wellesley and Mass General for Children (both part of the Mass General Brigham health system) and diagnosed with appendicitis. After a routine appendectomy failed to alleviate her symptoms, she underwent additional testing, which revealed something much more alarming and unexpected: a two-inch-long benign tumor on her pancreas. Lindsey was transferred to Massachusetts General Hospital for spleen-sparing pancreas surgery with Dr. Masiakos and Motaz Qadan, MD, PhD, hepatobiliary and pancreatic surgical oncologist. Read her story: www.massgeneral.org/children/news/lindsey-scheyer-patient-story Visit Mass General for Children: https://www.massgeneral.org/children

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Understanding Lymphedema
videoDescription: An estimated 10 million people suffer from lymphedema in the United States alone, however, many people go undiagnosed or untreated. Lymphedema is chronic swelling (edema) in your body that occurs when your lymph system is injured or blocked. The edema can occur anywhere in the body but more frequently occurs in the arms or legs. Currently, there is no cure for lymphedema. In this presentation from March 8, 2023, Catherine Holley, RN, CLT, gives an overview of lymphedema ‚Äì its causes, stages, and the importance of early diagnosis and treatment. Having lived with lymphedema for 38 years, Catherine‚Äôs personal experience adds a unique perspective to this often-misunderstood condition.

videoTitle: Training the Health Professional Workforce for 1.5 Degrees and Beyond
videoDescription: Health professionals occupy a critical position in the response to climate change. However, globally, few public health, medical or nursing programs yet teach their students about climate impacts, and evidence suggests that current training programs are inadequate to meet current and future population-level health needs. This presentation will address 1) what are the essential climate-related skills and knowledge that health practitioners must possess; 2) how novel curricula and education approaches can be created to bridge this gap; 3) how institutions can collaborate to form educational coalitions.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: The Intersection Between Climate Change and Malnutrition on Health
videoDescription: The United States ranks second in the world in carbon emissions and fourth in greenhouse gas emissions related to diet. Moreover, malnutrition (both obesity and undernutrition) and climate change can be described as a global syndemic ‚Äì three pandemics that affect most people worldwide ‚Äì because of their interactions, adverse effects on each other, and common underlying factors they have on social and economic health. This presentation from February 22, 2023, explores the impact of climate change on food access and nutrition and discusses individual and policy-focused recommendations to address these intersecting threats to public health. This program is part of the Climate Change and Health Series. videoTitle: Housing, Climate Change, and Environmental Justice
videoDescription: Housing is key to both climate mitigation and adaptation, but designing optimal interventions is challenging given the need to consider carbon emissions, indoor air, thermal comfort, energy bills, and more. These issues are particularly challenging for low-income households, where energy insecurity can pose considerable challenges and access to air conditioning and adequate ventilation are more limited. This presentation will give an overview of the multiple connections between housing and climate change, considering exposure disparities and complex tradeoffs that occur in a warming climate.

videoTitle: The Neurology of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex: Epilepsy, Cognition and Behavior
videoDescription: Elizabeth Thiele, MD, PhD Director, Herscot Center for Tuberous Sclerosis Complex The Neurology of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex: Epilepsy, Cognition and Behavior Dr. Elizabeth A. Thiele is a neurologist and epileptologist at Massachusetts General Hospital. She is a world-renowned expert in TSC and epilepsy. She organized and established the Herscot Center for Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, a multidisciplinary comprehensive clinical program for TSC, as well as a ketogenic diet clinic to treat and manage patients with epilepsy. She is also the Director of the Pediatric Epilepsy Service at Mass General and a Professor in Neurology at Harvard Medical School. Dr. Thiele's research and clinical interests include the role of diet in epilepsy treatment, genotype-phenotype correlation in TSC, the role of epilepsy surgery in management of intractable epilepsy, outcomes following infantile spasms, and neuropsychological profiles in relationship to tuber number and location in TSC.
caption: false

videoTitle: Modern and Safe Strategies to Improve Quality of Life
videoDescription: Mark Richardson, MD, PhD Pediatric and Adult Epilepsy Surgeon Modern and Safe Strategies to Improve Quality of Life Dr. Richardson specializes in functional neurosurgery, surgeries that aim to improve brain function and quality of life. Dr. Richardson performs Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS), Responsive Neurostimulation (RNS), and laser ablation surgery for people with epilepsy. These surgeries are minimally invasive because they are done through small openings, where the brain is seen using MRI.
caption: false

videoTitle: Managing Anxiety in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex
videoDescription: Leigh Horne Mebel, MSW, LICSW, BCD, ACSW Managing Anxiety in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex Leigh is a licensed independent clinical social worker and is affiliated with Massachusetts General Hospital. Some of what she can offer to families include helping people become more self-aware, helping people cope and manage challenges, and providing resources for an individual or their family. Some concerns people often bring to her are coping with anxiety and depression, concerns about relationships, or concerns about decision making. Leigh‚Äôs favorite part of her day to day is having the opportunity to talk with patients about their lives and learning how she can support them, helping them identify their strengths and building those strengths, and helping them become their best selves. Leigh has been working with people with TSC for ~18 years. She loves helping patients with TSC to understand their needs, to set goals, and work towards those goals. Leigh‚Äôs goals for the upcoming year include continuing the TSC adult support group and starting the TSC young adult support group.

videoTitle: From Chaos to Clarity: Defining Palliative Care & Hospice Across the Trajectory of Dementia
videoDescription: Julia M. Gallagher, MD The trajectory of illness that a person living with dementia will follow is often long and winding. Where along that trajectory can palliative care offer support and guidance? How does palliative care differ from hospice? And just what is hospice now that you mentioned it? Dr. Gallagher will review the differences between palliative care and hospice and reveal how expansive a person‚Äôs palliative care team can be when one considers care from this interdisciplinary perspective. Dr. Gallagher is the Medical Director of the MGH/Mass General Brigham Home Based Palliative Care Program and joined the MGH Division of Palliative Care and Geriatric Medicine in 2014 to help develop the Program. Prior to joining MGH, Dr. Gallagher was a member of the Divisions of Palliative Care and Hospital Medicine at UMass Memorial Medical Center. She served on the in-patient palliative care consult team, as a senior ward-attending hospitalist and as the Hospice Medical Director for UMass Memorial Home Health and Hospice. Contact the www.dementiacarecollaborative.org for more information.
caption: false

videoTitle: Coaching for the Caregiver
videoDescription: Beth Nolan, PhD Director of Research and Policy Positive Approach to Care¬Æ (PAC) This session addresses awareness and methods for improving hands-on skills of dementia caregiving. Attendees will be introduced to a variety of physical techniques and cuing strategies to facilitate care. The session also addresses communication strategies, with an emphasis on connecting emotionally with the person living with dementia. The goal of this session is for attendees to have improved care interactions with those living with dementia. Beth A. D. Nolan holds a Ph.D. in gerontology, and master‚Äôs degrees in in human development and in applied behavior analysis. Formerly an Assistant Professor and the Senior Associate Director for the Evaluation Institute at the University of Pittsburgh's Graduate School of Public Health, her work centered on translation of evidence-based programs into human services. She now works at Positive Approach to Care¬Æ (PAC), leading online and in-person education and resources designed to help caregivers become care partners. Contact the www.dementiacarecollaborative.org for more information.
caption: false

videoTitle: Evaluation & Treatment of Anxiety & Depression for Adults with Cognitive Impairment or Dementia
videoDescription: Olivia Okereke, MD, MS Associate Professor of Psychiatry, Harvard Medical School Director, Geriatric Psychiatry, Department of Psychiatry, Mass General Hospital and Harvard Medical School This session addresses the pharmacological and non-pharmacological methods to treat anxiety and depression in older adults with dementia and Alzheimer‚Äôs. Dr Okereke breaks this information down for the lay person. Her expertise and approach are informative and accessible. Olivia I. Okereke, MD, MS is Director of Geriatric Psychiatry and Director of the MGH Psychiatry Center for Racial Equity and Justice in the Department of Psychiatry at Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH), Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, and Associate Professor in Epidemiology at the Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health. Dr. Okereke is committed to research in late-life mental health and well-being. Her program has been funded by numerous awards from the National Institutes of Health (NIH), Harvard Medical School and research foundations. Contact the www.dementiacarecollaborative.org for more information.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Surviving and Thriving After Breast Cancer - A Roadmap
videoDescription: A breast cancer diagnosis is life-changing and can bring physical and emotional challenges. Research has shown that breast cancer survivors who adopt healthy lifestyle behaviors have improved health, well-being, and quality of life. These behaviors include healthy eating habits, regular exercise, stress management, social connections, good sleep habits, and avoiding risky substances such as drugs and alcohol. In this presentation from October 25, 2022, Amy Comander, MD, DipABLM, Dana Haggett, MS, RN, FNP-BC, and Elizabeth Abraham, BSN, RN, review these recommendations and lead an interactive conversation to empower patients to adopt healthy behaviors. They are also joined by a patient who shares how she adopted these lifestyle habits after her breast cancer diagnosis.
caption: false

videoTitle: Drs. Rudy Tanzi and Gene Bowman: Beyond the Lab ‚Äì Beginning Clinical Trials at the McCance Center
videoDescription: Co-Director and Co-Founder of the McCance Center for Brain Health Dr. Tanzi, and the McCance Center‚Äôs new Clinical Trials Director Dr. Gene Bowman, discuss the opportunity ahead ‚Äì moving to clinical trials with unique combinations from 200+ FDA approved drugs and safe natural products already shown to have impact in Dr. Tanzi‚Äôs ‚Äúbrain in a dish model‚Äù in the lab.

videoTitle: Preclinical Gene Therapy for Tuberous Sclerosis Complex by Dr. Breakefield and Dr. Haidar
videoDescription: Xandra Breakefield, PhD, is a research scientist at Mass General Hospital. What first started as identifying disease genes progressed to gene replacement therapy and then applying gene therapy skills on tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) patients by Elizabeth Thiele, MD, PhD. Dr. Breakefield plays a huge role with the Herscot Center as she researches to hopefully find a cure for TSC patients. Dr. Breakefield has been doing scientific research for 40+ years. Dr. Breakefield and Edwina Abou Haidar, MD, will also highlight their early studies in gene therapy for tuberous sclerosis complex.
caption: false

videoTitle: Dermatologic considerations in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex by Dr. Grevelink and Dr. Siegel
videoDescription: Joop Grevelink, MD, PhD, specializes in general dermatology, skin surgery and laser dermatology at Boston Dermatology and Laser Center and is affiliated with Massachusetts General Hospital. Dr. Grevelink was initially drawn to dermatology because he is a visual learner. With his background in laser engineering, he got involved with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) early on and has been performing numerous laser skin treatments for and conducting research with patients afflicted by TSC. Many of his TSC patients have been with him from childhood or adolescence through adulthood. He has also mentored many health care providers throughout his 36-year career in medicine and is excited that Julia Siegel, MD, will continue to care for his patients. He will be retiring soon and is eager to continue to follow new developments and research efforts in TSC.

videoDescription: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted all our lives in unprecedented ways. It has also severely impacted breast cancer screening. videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Preventing Bullying and Protecting Children
videoDescription: Bullying is an issue that can negatively impact children, teens, and young adults. It is important to recognize bullying and intervene appropriately while also working toward prevention efforts to keep kids safe. In this presentation from October 4, 2022, Justine Dellaria, LICSW, Social Worker on the Child Protection Team at Mass General for Children (MGfC), discusses the difference between conflict and bullying, the impact bullying has on youth, and what can protect children from bullying or increase their risk ‚Äì whether they are the victim of bullying or are bullying others. videoTitle: Close Interaction Between Epithelial Cells and Mononuclear Phagocytes in the Epididymis
videoDescription: This microscopy image shows projections of a type of immune cells, mononuclear phagocytes (green), in very close proximity to epithelial narrow cells (red) in the epididymis. Understanding how these epithelial cells communicate with immune cells will help us better understand certain causes of male infertility and develop male contraception methods. Battistone et al., 2020 J Cell Sci. 2019 Nov 18;133(5):jcs233239. The Battistone Lab at Massachusetts General Hospital is focused on exploring the molecular basis of mucosal immunity in the urogenital tract, with the aim to identify new diagnostic and therapeutic targets for kidney injury and male infertility.
caption: false

videoTitle: Epithelial Cells Send ‚ÄúNanotubes‚Äù in the Epididymis | Massachusetts General Hospital
videoDescription: Confocal microscopy image showing protrusions of clear cells (green) that interact with sperm (their head contain DNA [blue]) in the epididymis. Battistone et al., 2020 J Cell Sci. 2019 Nov 18;133(5):jcs233239. videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Cataracts and Eye Health
videoDescription: Cataract surgery is the most commonly performed surgery in the United States. It has become safer and more effective than ever. He also shares tips and misconceptions on keeping the eyes and vision healthy. videoTitle: Blum Center Program: An Overview of Heat-Related Illness in a Climate-Changing World

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Tips to Promote Safe Video Game and Digital Media Use Habits
videoDescription: Video games and digital media have become one of the most favorite play activities for our children, and digital media has infused far into their (and our) daily lives. Parents and providers express a lot of concern about the effects of violent or suggestive content of video games and digital media on their children. However, existing research has not been able to conclusively establish any such link. Instead, findings reveal the several circumstances of digital media access to be associated with overall wellbeing of children. In this presentation from June 30, 2022, Atilla Ceranoglu, MD, a psychiatrist in Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at MGfC and Adult Psychiatry at Mass General, shares tips on how to help your child build good digital media habits while playing their favorite video games, social media outlets, or the internet. This program is a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and Mass General for Children.

videoDescription: Sabrina Paganoni, MD, PhD presented this week‚Äôs updates on the HEALEY ALS Platform Trial and answered questions from the audience. We were joined by guest speaker Bruce Rosenblum. Professionally, Bruce brings over 35 years of experience to his role as the Vice President of Content and Workflow solutions at Atypon Systems, where he has spent his career working to accelerate the speed of research publication. Bruce was diagnosed with ALS in 2017, and accelerating research became a personal matter. He has participated in multiple clinical trials and research studies, and he currently serves as a member of the Patient Advisory Committee for the Platform Trial's companion Expanded Access Program (EAP). Bruce's work as an ALS advocate centers on educating others about living with ALS and the opportunities that exist for patients to participate in ALS research.

videoTitle: Sweet Potato Summer Salad
videoDescription: Ingredients: ~ 2cups sweet potatoes ‚Äì peeled, cut into ~ 1 inch dice. 1 cup canned black beans ‚Äì rinsed. 1 cup corn ‚Äì canned ( rinsed/drained) or fresh boiled and cut from cob. ~ 1 cup chopped fresh cilantro. ~1/3 cup lime juice 1 tsp lime zest (optional) 3-4 Tbsp of olive oil. 1 tsp cumin 2 Tbsp honey Salt and pepper to taste. Optional ‚Äì dash of cayenne or hot sauce. Or little diced fresh jalapeno. Pumpkin seeds/chopped pecans are also delicious in this salad. Preparation: 1. Boil sweet potato until just tender. Let cool briefly. 2. Add black beans, corn and cilantro to sweet potato, toss gently. 3. Whisk together lime juice, olive oil, cumin, honey and salt and pepper. 4. Add dressing to potato mixture and gently toss. Let salad sit ~ 15 minutes and taste again. Adjust seasoning if you need.
caption: false

videoTitle: Basic Lemon Hummus
videoDescription: Ingredients: 1 can chickpeas ‚Äì drained and rinsed 2-4 Tbsp water. 2-3 Tbsp olive oil 1 tsp lemon zest. 1 Tbsp lemon juice. Salt and pepper to taste. Preparation: 1. Add all the ingredients to a food processor. 2. Blend until smooth and creamy ‚Äì add more water if need until desired texture. 3. Let it sit for ~ 30 minutes and taste ‚Äì adjust your seasoning if needed. 4. Serve drizzled with a little more olive oil on top and some crispy vegetable and whole grain crackers. Now you have your basic ‚Äì here are some add-ins you can stir in: Herbs ‚Äì thyme, oregano, rosemary, parsley, cilantro, dill Spices ‚Äì cumin, red pepper flakes, cayenne pepper, smoked paprika, garlic powder Other ‚Äì finely diced tomato, finely dice jalapeno, finely chopped fresh pineapple, chopped olives, chopped capers, finely chopped garlic

videoTitle: "Traffic-related Air Pollution" & "Effects of Nuclear Weapons and Avenues for Clinician Advocacy"
videoDescription: Traffic-related air pollution (TRAP) has important adverse effects on childhood health. Dr. Carlos A. Camargo will review recent studies on TRAP and asthma/allergy, including new findings from his ongoing multicenter US-based cohorts, and summarize compelling scientific evidence to support policy changes. The invasion of Ukraine has led to devastating humanitarian consequences and has turned public attention back to the threat of nuclear weapons. The climate effects of a nuclear exchange are of particular importance to nuclear policy. We will review this evidence as well as the actions clinicians and their allies have taken to change the course of nuclear weapons policy.

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Fostering and Preventing Depression, Stress, and Suicide in Youth
videoDescription: Resilience is not an inborn trait, but a skill that is learned through engagement with friends, family, other important relationships, and the community. Resilience is also learned through awareness and becoming attuned to knowing your feelings, behavior, attitudes, and how they impact yourself and others. In this presentation from May 9, 2022, Eugene (Gene) Beresin, MD, MA, of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at MGHfC, shares how parents, families, and caregivers can understand the signs of depression, stress, and suicide in young people, as well as guidelines for caregivers and youth on how to prevent these serious conditions. Beresin also shares when these conditions cannot be prevented, how early intervention can be helpful, and what public mental health education can do to help families, young people, and caregivers learn more about psychiatric disorders and the psychosocial issues that contribute to them. This program is a collaboration between the Maxwell & Eleanor Blum Patient and Family Learning Center and Mass General for Children.

videoTitle: Pasta Primavera
videoDescription: A simple delicious meal that celebrates spring. Ingredients: 2 garlic cloves, chopped fine ~ ¬º of a red onion (~1/2 cup), slivered ~ ¬Ω tsp red pepper flakes ( or to taste) 1 red, yellow or orange bell pepper, cut into strips ~ 2 cups broccoli florets cut small 1 bunch asparagus, tops only. (save rest for soup) ~ 1cup cherry tomato, cut in half Zest of half lemon (or ~ 1 tsp) ~ 1 Tbsp lemon juice ~ 1 cup loosely packed chopped basil ( or half chopped parsley) ~ ¬º - 1/3 box of whole grain pasta of your choice. Directions: 1. Boil water for pasta, cook pasta according to directions until just al dente. Drain and set aside. 2. Heat ~ 2-3 Tbsp olive oil over med-high heat until oil slightly shimmers, add garlic, red onion, red pepper flakes. Saute ~ 2 minutes, add bell peppers. Continue to cook until peppers are slightly softened. 3. Add broccoli florets, stir to combine and cook until broccoli is almost tender (you may want to cover the pan briefly). 4. Add asparagus, cherry tomatoes and lemon zest. Cook until asparagus is tender and tomatoes are softened and losing their juices. All the vegetables should be tender at this point or cook a bit longer if needed. 5. Add lemon juice. Add pasta and toss. The pasta and vegetables should be about 50/50. If you have extra pasta just save for later. 6. Add herbs, parmesan cheese and season with salt and pepper to taste. Drizzle with additional olive oil if needed.
caption: false

videoTitle: French Grated Carrot Salad
videoDescription: Carrot salad ¬∑ 1 pound carrots, peeled ¬∑ 1 small beet, peeled -optional ¬∑ 2 tablespoons finely snipped chives or chopped green onion or slivered red onion ¬∑ 2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh parsley ( or cilantro or tarragon) ¬∑ Optional: 1 can (15 ounces) chickpeas, rinsed and drained, or 1 ¬Ω cups cooked chickpea Dressing ¬∑ 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil ¬∑ 2 tablespoons lemon juice or lime juice or even orange juice ¬∑ 2 teaspoons honey ( maple syrup) ¬∑ 1 teaspoon Dijon mustard ¬∑ ¬Ω teaspoon ground cumin ¬∑ ¬º teaspoon fine sea salt INSTRUCTIONS 1. To prepare the carrots: You can grate them on the large holes of a box grater, or process them in a food processor fitted with a grating attachment. You‚Äôll end up with about 3 cups grated carrots. 2. To prepare the beets: Grate on large holes of box grater. ~ ¬Ω cup or so is needed 3. Place the carrots and beets in a medium serving bowl. Add the chives, parsley and optional chickpeas to the bowl. 4. To make the dressing, whisk all of the ingredients together in a small bowl until completely blended. 5. Pour the dressing over the carrot mixture and stir until the mixture is evenly coated in dressing. For best flavor, allow the salad to marinate for 20 minutes before serving. Toss again before serving. This salad keeps well in the refrigerator, covered, for about 4 days.

videoTitle: New Techniques for Mapping Brain Networks
videoDescription: Mass General Neurology researchers are developing increasingly accurate ways of mapping electrical signals as they travel from one part of the brain to another using direct electrical stimulation. The more accurate, and predictable, these maps become, the more precisely doctors will be able to target interventions for epilepsy and other disorders. Learn more about our research: https://www.massgeneral.org/neurology/research/sydney-cash-cortical-physiology-laboratory Associated paper (Open Access): https://doi.org/10.1016/j.brs.2022.02.017 Data from this research has also been made available here as part of Open Science efforts: https://doi.org/10.18120/j3k5-1m18

videoDescription: How can we take care of our brains and why does it matter? videoTitle: Colonoscopy Risks and Benefits
videoDescription: A colonoscopy is a procedure that involves an examination of the entire colon and requires bowel preparation and sedation. Screening tests are done to detect or prevent cancer in asymptomatic patients; when concerning signs or symptoms are present, diagnostic testing should be performed. There are a number of stool-based, endoscopic, or radiologic tests available for Colorectal cancer (CRC) screening, though choice may be driven by patient preference and local availability. Watch this video to learn about the purpose and benefits of the exam, how the colonoscopy procedure is performed, and the potential risks and complications.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Living from the Heart: Tips to Lead a More Active Life for a Healthier Heart
videoDescription: Physical activity is one of the best (and most fun) ways to keep your heart healthy! Whether indoors, outdoors, walking, swimming, or simply playing in the yard at a local park, there are lots of options when it comes to adding more movement into your family and child‚Äôs day. In this presentation from March 3, 2022, Lorraine Schratz, MD, an attending physician in Pediatric Cardiology at MGHfC and Elizabeth Barth, MS, RD, LDN, a registered dietitian at MGHfC, share the essentials to helping children and their families on their way to healthier hearts by leading physically active lives. Both Schratz and Barth are a part of the team in the Raising Healthy Hearts clinic within Pediatric Cardiology. The Raising Healthy Hearts Program focuses on lifestyle and behavior change in the setting of weight and cholesterol management.

videoTitle: The DACCPM‚Äôs History of Innovation
videoDescription: The first successful public demonstration of the use of ether for surgical anesthesia took place at Massachusetts General Hospital in 1846‚Äîthe start of many advances in the field led by those at Mass General. Hear from several members of the Department of Anesthesia, Critical Care and Pain Medicine (DACCPM) about the department‚Äôs history of innovation in anesthesia. About the DACCPM: The Department of Anesthesia, Critical Care and Pain Medicine (DACCPM) at Massachusetts General Hospital offers world-class patient care, the finest education for medical students and residents, innovative research laboratories and a team of accomplished faculty. Each year, we provide anesthesia services for more than 50,000 procedures in 67 operating rooms and 25 additional locations on the Mass General campus. On October 16, 1846, the first successful public demonstration of the use of ether for surgical anesthesia was performed, making pain-free surgery possible. This historical event took place in the amphitheater of the Bulfinch Building at Massachusetts General Hospital. #MassGeneral #MGH #Anesthesia Visit our website: https://www.massgeneral.org/anesthesia/ Find us on social: Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/mghanesthesia Instagram: http://www.instagram.com/mghanesthesia Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/mghanesthesia
caption: false

videoTitle: 175 Years and Counting
videoDescription: In October 2021, Massachusetts General Hospital commemorated the 175th anniversary of the first successful public demonstration of the use of ether for surgical anesthesia. Hear from members of the Department of Anesthesia, Critical Care and Pain Medicine about the history of anesthesia at Mass General. About the DACCPM: The Department of Anesthesia, Critical Care and Pain Medicine (DACCPM) at Massachusetts General Hospital offers world-class patient care, the finest education for medical students and residents, innovative research laboratories and a team of accomplished faculty. Each year, we provide anesthesia services for more than 50,000 procedures in 67 operating rooms and 25 additional locations on the Mass General campus. On October 16, 1846, the first successful public demonstration of the use of ether for surgical anesthesia was performed, making pain-free surgery possible. This historical event took place in the amphitheater of the Bulfinch Building at Massachusetts General Hospital. #MassGeneral #MGH #Anesthesia Visit our website: https://www.massgeneral.org/anesthesia/ Find us on social: Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/mghanesthesia Instagram: http://www.instagram.com/mghanesthesia Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/mghanesthesia
caption: false

videoTitle: Pioneering Patient Safety

videoTitle: Blum Center: MGHfC Series - Planning for a Successful Transition from Pediatric to Adult Care
videoDescription: While families are often very familiar with transitions for their child as they grow and progress, transitioning from pediatric to adult care can seem overwhelming and can often take families by surprise. This may be even more true for youth and young adults with special health care needs who use the healthcare system more often. In this presentation from February 2, 2022, Evangeline Galvez, MD, an attending physician in Internal Medicine at the MGH Revere HealthCare Center and Pediatric Primary Care at MGHfC, presents evidence driven elements and resources to help plan a successful individualized transition to adult care. She discusses the differences between pediatric and adult care, suggested timelines to transition, and what to consider when children transition to adult care. She also shares resources to help families and their children plan for transitions.

videoTitle: Infection as a Trigger for Arterial Ischemic Stroke: Lessons from Childhood Stroke Research
videoDescription: In this Mass General Neurology Grand Rounds lecture, UCSF Professor Heather Fullerton, MD discusses mechanisms by which infection can contribute to the pathogenesis of arterial ischemic stroke. Dr. Fullerton is the Founder and President of the International Pediatric Stroke Organization (IPSO), a nonprofit organization that aims to improve the prevention, care and lifelong outcomes of children with cerebrovascular disease worldwide. She is a co-mentorship officer and an executive committee member of the NINDS Child Neurologist Career Development Program (CNCDP), a national K12 program that aims to train and support the next generation of academic child neurologists. Learn more about Neurology Grand Rounds here: https://www.massgeneral.org/neurology/education-and-training/grand-rounds

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Rheumatoid Arthritis ‚Äì The Most Common Type of Autoimmune Arthritis
videoDescription: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disease seen in up to 1% of the United States population. While it commonly affects the small joints in the hands and feet, it can also affect larger joints. In this presentation from January 24, 2022, Dr. Duncan Moore discusses the science behind rheumatoid arthritis, the symptoms that patients with this disease experience, how it affects patients and their families, the importance of early treatment, and advances in medications to treat it.

videoTitle: Winter Vegetable Mulligatawny Soup
videoDescription: Winter Vegetable Mulligatawny Soup 3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, divided 1 medium onion, finely chopped 2 medium carrots, finely chopped 1 medium parsnip, peeled and finely chopped 4 cups peeled diced acorn squash or butternut squash 1 medium green/red apple, peeled and finely chopped 1 tablespoon curry powder 2 cloves garlic, minced 1 teaspoon grated fresh ginger 4 cups low-sodium vegetable broth or water or chicken broth 1 (14 ounce) can no-salt-added diced tomatoes 14 oz can of chick peas or white beans or lentils ¬º cup chopped fresh cilantro 1/4 cup chopped roasted salted peanuts for garnish chopped fresh cilantro for garnish Directions Step 1: Chop all veggies and measure spices Step 2: Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a large saucepan over medium heat until shimmering. Add onion, carrots and parsnip and cook until the onions are translucent, about 6 minutes. Add squash, apple, curry powder, 2 cloves garlic and ginger and cook, stirring, until fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes. Add broth/water, tomatoes and bean and stir to combine. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat to maintain a low simmer, cover and cook until the squash and lentils are tender, about 20 minutes. Step 3: Gently mash some of the soup with a potato masher to achieve desired consistency. (Alternatively, transfer half the soup to a blender and puree. Use caution when blending hot liquids.) Garnish the soup with cilantro and chopped peanuts.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center Program: Heart Disease and HIV ‚Äì Getting to the HEART of the Matter
videoDescription: People with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are living longer thanks to the introduction of antiretroviral therapy. However, research has found that those living with HIV are at an increased risk for heart disease even if they are well-treated on antiretroviral therapies. In this presentation from January 19, 2022, Suman Srinivasa, MD, MS, Allie Walpert, MSN, FNP-BC, and Grace Shen, BS with the MGH Metabolism Unit provide a general overview of heart disease and how it relates to those living with HIV.
caption: false

videoTitle: Blum Center: The Down and Dirty on ‚ÄúClean‚Äù Skincare Products and Are They Truly Better for the Skin?
videoDescription: In this presentation from January 18, 2022, Dr. JiaDe (Jeff) Yu explores the market phenomenon of ‚Äúclean‚Äù skincare products and what this actually means. He discusses whether ‚Äúclean‚Äù skincare products are actually better for you, have a lower risk of allergies, and are less likely to have potential harmful effects to your body compared to regular products. Finally, he shares the truth behind some commonly avoided ‚Äúallergens‚Äù and ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù ingredients using recently published data.

videoTitle: Easy Roasted Root Vegetables
videoDescription: 2 medium parsnips 2 Carrots 1 Sweet Potato 1 Onion 1 Orange 1-2 Tbsp olive oil 1 Tbsp oregano or Italian seasoning 1 tsp garlic powder Pinch red pepper flakes ¬Ω tsp salt and pepper 1. Preheat oven to 400. Line sheet pan with foil. 2. Peel and cut root vegetables into ~ 1 inch pieces ‚Äì most important is that all are about the same size give or take. Place in large bowl. 3. Add oil, oregano or Italian seasoning, garlic powder, red pepper flakes, salt and pepper. 4. Toss well to coat all the pieces. 5. Place on sheet pan in single layer. 6. Place in oven ‚Äì roast ~ 10-12 minutes, using spatula toss the pieces around and roast for another ~10-15 minutes until golden brown. They are done when easily pierced with a fork. Toss with some squeezed orange juice or Zest!

videoTitle: Research Advances from Mass General Orthopaedics
videoDescription: Researchers from the Department of Orthopaedics discuss the clinical and translational work they are doing at Massachusetts General Hospital.
